docs.snippet: Foreign filmmakers and actors may quietly make a career in their native lands, but if the Oscar juggernaut takes them up, the quiet days are over....
docs.lead_paragraph: Working actors in far-flung lands often put together a lifetime of work under the radar of Hollywood, but a single appearance in the Oscar scrum can change that in a heartbeat. Something tells me that we will be seeing a lot more of our coin-flipping friendo.
docs.abstract: Foreign filmmakers and actors may quietly make a career in their native lands, but if the Oscar juggernaut takes them up, the quiet days are over.

docs.snippet: "Sid Ganis, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and chief defender of its strike-threatened Oscar show, took the gloves off on Monday. Well, one glove anyway."...

docs.snippet: Yes, the Oscar's are bloated, slow and often boring -- that's part of the point....
docs.lead_paragraph: Even though the Oscars remain somewhat in doubt, the annual fish-in-a-barrel piece about dumping the whole thing gets a workout, this time by Marc Peyser of Newsweek.
docs.abstract: Yes, the Oscar's are bloated, slow and often boring -- that's part of the point.

docs.snippet: A toast to Bill Cunningham among many fashion shows....
docs.lead_paragraph: Whenever I go to some black-tie affair at the Waldorf, I leave thinking of my father, Eugene Horyn, an ex-newspaperman. I can't help it. He loved all that big-city stuff, and I don't take any of it for granted even when my shoes feel too small. I went to the Waldorf tonight because Bill Cunningham was being honored, among others, by the Citizens Committee for New York, and the Times took two tables.
docs.abstract: A toast to Bill Cunningham among many fashion shows.
